description:
Penicillium oxalicum is a species of fungus that belongs to the genus Penicillium. It is a common soil-borne mold that is known for its ability to produce various secondary metabolites, including oxalic acid and other organic acids.

This species is characterized by its distinct, brush-like conidiophores (spore-bearing structures) and small, green to blue-green colored colonies. The fungus is known to be widely distributed in soil and plant matter, and it plays a role in the decomposition of organic matter in the environment.

Penicillium oxalicum is of particular interest in the field of biotechnology due to its potential applications in the production of various enzymes, organic acids, and other valuable compounds. Additionally, some strains of this species have been investigated for their ability to degrade certain pollutants and their potential use in bioremediation processes.
